Situation1: All household chores must be coordinated because relatives are visiting, and the home needs to be fully presentable.
Expectation2: Respect the privacy and confidentiality of the people you are helping
Situation2: They are sorting files that contain detailed medical histories that must not be disclosed.
Story: This morning, I woke up to the sound of my husband bustling around the kitchen, clearly stressed about the relatives arriving tonight. As his wife, I know he expects me to help make the house spotless and welcoming. The pressure is on—every cushion fluffed, every dish put away, every surface gleaming. But today is also my volunteer day at the clinic, and I promised to help sort confidential medical files. The coordinator reminded us how crucial it is to respect the privacy of every patient; one slip could mean betraying someone’s trust. My phone buzzes with a message from my husband: “Can you come home early? There’s still so much to do.” At the same time, my supervisor at the clinic hands me a stack of files, her eyes serious. I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in—my family’s expectations for a perfect home, and my duty to protect the privacy of vulnerable people. My heart pounds as I stand in the middle, torn, knowing I can’t give both roles what they demand from me at the same time.
